job_title: Coordinator II in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
- Full time employee benefits are fantastic: 14% 401K contribution regardless of employee contribution, free tuition for employees and their dependents (including domestic partners) up to ten credits per semester, life insurance, vision and dental insurance, and amazing medical insurance even if the premiums went up this year - compared to most private sector employer options, the insurance premiums and coverage are dreamy.
- Besides the inane requirement to come to the office for administrative work, the office facilities are great and the company is generous is making sure employees have the tools they need to do their job, at least for full-time staff.
- Annual cost of living salary increases for full-time employees were 2.5% in 2021 and 6% in 2022. Not nearly enough to match inflation but an effort was made.
- Generous vacation and sick leave - full-time non-exempt employees begin accruing 1 sick day and 1 vacation day a month. Exempt employees earn 1 sick day and 17.6 vacation hours a month.
cons:
- Despite cost of living increases and generous benefits, wages for all positions below VP level are abhorrently, unconscionably low. Also, the fact that almost none of the benefits are extended to part-time employees is dubious. 
- The only food option on the main campus is burgers and chicken strips???
- Entire departments remain entirely opposed to remote work in the third year of the pandemic, while other departments continue to work almost entirely remotely? When I ask my manager why I can't work remotely more than one day a week, I'm given excuses about other departments "abusing" remote work. 
- The utter ineptitude and immaturity of leadership is truly, draw-droppingly astounding. That would be disheartening enough, but SLCC is also supposed to be an institution that catalyzes economic mobility and opportunity, making our communities stronger. To watch it be led by a group of bickering sycophants not interested in even paying livable wages does not exactly leave one's employees... inspired. And that's not even mentioning the scandals and cover-ups. You can just search us in local paper headlines. 
- Insert highly ethically questionable nature of employing primarily adjunct teaching force here. 
- Like most higher education institutions, SLCC is not interested in operating efficiently. Rather than a single institution moving towards an end, the college is a series of self-interested slow-moving silos fighting for resources in a dying industry and it is not pretty to watch. If you're going to join the fray, bring popcorn.

job_title: Admissions Advisor I in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Perhaps the most diverse workplace in Utah as far as work experience, ages, ethnicities and unique backgrounds. SLCC really invests in its employees and you are not expected to work overtime to make up for time spent on professional development opportunities and in fact, you are encouraged to take on additional projects (such as committees).
cons: After leaving, I found out that my pay was extremely inequitable in comparison to my male counterparts. I was earning over $20k less than a man who was hired simultaneously and was less qualified than I was. It was a hard lesson to learn that you can't get what you don't ask for.

job_title: Administrative Assistant II in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: 8-4:30 M-F job with hour-long lunch breaks, don't usually have to adjust time, most bosses are flexible if you're going to school or need to adjust hours. Pretty good benefits. Time off between Christmas and New Years (and for other holidays).
cons: Lower paying than a lot of other jobs that I imagine have a similar workload, and little room for negotiation on pay. (In a previous admin position, a supervisor tried to promote me and with the title change would come significantly higher pay. It was approved all the way through the President's Office, but HR rejected the request, stating that the agreed upon rate would leapfrog me over too many other people who had been in that title for longer. It was frustrating.)

job_title: Office Support Specialist in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The Management has always been great to me. The benifits for full time staff is really nice, health insurance, access to the gym for free, programs to assist getting access to technology if you don't have it that greatly helps with the cost. There also free courses for full time employees. SLCC has been the greatest experience I have had in my working career I think its probably a combination of the environment, the people and being able to see and learn the inner workings of a college. They also give out gifts for workers during the year for The Holiday season and they have gave out gift cards for Thanksgiving as well which has helped me and my family a lot. You also get a lot of days off for all of the major holidays. I really enjoy the 2-3 weeks we get off for the holidays in December. I could not recommend working here enough.
cons: The pay is not amazing its not bad and they are usually offer yearly increases which is greatly appreciated, and I wish they offered more benefits for part time staff.

You'll be treated well if you are "brown" and racially diverse, or if you are in the Mormon club. Everyone else beware and be prepared to struggle thanklessly or be punished for high performance. One department clique will say you're under-qualified, and another will say you're overqualified. If echo chambers bother you, keep looking.

review_title: Academia is unique - Different departments/areas are very different
job_title: Non-Academic in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
1. The ability to help change people's futures, making an impact is real and rewarding.
2. Embracing best practices (varies by area.)
3. Many staff are motivated to do what is best and right.
4. Large presence in the community by nature the sheer size of student body and multiple locations.
5. Starting to engage local companies to determine what prepares students for work.
cons:
1. Compensation can be significantly below market rates.
2. Poor performers are left in place, even when it creates significant brand damage in the community.  Degrees trump ability, and good results often get ignored
3. Good performers are overlooked and expected to carry the weight of poor hiring choices.
4. Education/Workforce alignment appears to focus on large (Fortune 1000) companies, versus majority of companies, under 500 employees.
5. Some senior managers are more concerned with appearance versus the one.
6. While education is supposed to identify and educate best practices-which proved decades ago that threats and intimidation are counter productive, some senior managers appear to be caught in the 1920's with threats being their go-to course of action.
7. Some senior managers propose changes and after they have been approved and implemented due they begin to determine and mitigate the consequences.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: I have worked at SLCC for several years, both part time and full time. There have been a lot of positive changes in leadership the past two years. The new president seems to truly care about the importance of having an affordable two year transfer college as well as vocational programs for those who are not seeking a transfer degree and would rather quickly join into the workforce. There seems to be a positive feeling of community among the employees over all, though it is impossible to avoid politics altogether. Amazing benefits for full time employees if you are able to find a full time position. The college is very dedicated to access, success, diversity and inclusivity. It creates a very positive environment for students and employees over all.
cons: SLCC runs primarily on part time employment and getting a full time position can take a very long time. Five years ago part time employees were able to accrue PTO, at a lower rate than full time staff, but it still helped keep finances stable during holidays or when you were sick. A part time staff member would have to work at SLCC for three years before gaining this benefit, so it was really set in place for individuals who were dedicated to the institution. This policy was done away with by the old SLCC president and still has not been reinstated despite change in leadership. Pay for part timers is not very competitive, but employment at SLCC provides opportunity to gain a variety of transferable skills and experience. Despite the challenges that come with being a part time employee at SLCC many people stay for a long time because they love their coworkers and the overall environment. I felt very lucky to finally get into a full time position.

review_title: Slow, mundane, and favoring particular people hinders progress. Uncreative.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The students and developing programs and services to meet their needs.
cons: Environment needs improvement. Applicant Interview process is slow, ineffective, includes too many people that are inappropriate to the decision making in the hiring process. The committee model is lackluster, uncreative, and takes the power away from the person and persons that will be directly working with the candidate.

The "good 'ol boys" network is in full swing there, specifically at the miller campus. very little continuity between the campus and other sites. always is cost-savings or cutting mode.
